content: On September 14, 2012, the President reported to Congress that a security force was deployed to Libya in response to the attack on the U.S. diplomatic post in Benghazi. The force was sent to support the security of U.S. personnel in Libya and an additional security force was also sent to Yemen. The President stated that these forces were equipped for combat but their purpose was solely to protect American citizens and property. The forces will remain in Libya and Yemen until the security situation improves. On June 15, 2012, President reported to Congress about U.S. Armed Forces deployments for counterterrorism operations, including approximately 90,000 troops in Afghanistan. U.S. combat-equipped forces were also deployed globally to enhance CT capabilities, with direct action taken in Somalia against al-Qa'ida members. The President reported efforts to eliminate terrorist threats posed by al-Qa'ida in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and mentioned additional measures against al-Qa'ida, the Taliban, and associated forces to protect U.S. citizens and interests. Military operations included the deployment of U.S. combat-equipped military personnel to Uganda as advisors. The deployment of approximately 90 U.S. military personnel to Uganda as advisors to regional forces working to apprehend Joseph Kony and other LRA leaders, with elements sent to forward locations in South Sudan, Congo, and CAR. These forces will only engage in self-defense. Additionally, the U.S. has around 817 military personnel in Kosovo and is prepared for maritime interception operations against international terrorists. The President's efforts aim to stop the movement, arming, and financing of international terrorist groups and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction by sea.
